Award.AwardTitle: Pacific Alliance for Supporting Individuals with Disabilities in STEM Fields Partnership (Pacific Alliance)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The "Pacific Alliance" for Students with Disabilities in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) project will increase the numbers of individuals with disabilities (IWD) in STEM postsecondary education programs and ultimately the STEM workforce in Hawai`i. The Pacific Alliance will employ a Community of Practice (COP) model as they provide students with disabilities (SWDs) STEM mentoring, academic skill interventions, research experiences, and internships. The primary institution, the University of Hawai`i at Manoa (UHM), will engage SWDs in feeder high schools on Oahu and Hawai`i Islands, SWDs at Honolulu Community College, Windward Community College and Hawai`i Community College, and SWDs at UHM and the University of Hawai`i at Hilo. The partnership team will employ evidence-based practices and promising interventions to advance students through critical junctures to degree completion and into the workforce or graduate STEM degree programs. The following objectives will be addressed by the Pacific Alliance:

1: Increase the recruitment of IWD in high schools on Oahu and Hawai`i Island who enroll in STEM degree programs at partnering 2 and 4 year institutes of higher education (IHE) by 20% per year (on Oahu, from 170 to 423 over 5 years; on Hawai`i Island, from 40 to 58 over 2 years).

2a. Increase the graduation rates (associate, baccalaureate, and graduate degrees) for STEM students with disabilities in Oahu based community colleges and university partner institutions by 10% per year from 10 graduates with Associates degree in STEM to 16; from 60 graduates with Bachelors degree to 97; from 12 graduates with Master?s or higher degrees in STEM to 19 over 5 years.

2b. Increase the graduation rates (associate, baccalaureate, and graduate degrees) for STEM students with disabilities in Hawai`i Island community colleges and university partner institution by 25% per year, from 5 graduates with Associates degree in STEM to 8; from 3 graduates with Bachelors degree to 5; and from 0 graduate with Masters or higher degrees in STEM to 1 over 2 years.

3: Increase successful entry (employed) rates of Alliance graduates (high school, associate, baccalaureate, and graduate) into STEM employment by 5% (from a baseline of 150 graduates to 191 over 5 years).

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of the Pacific Alliance project was to significantly increase the numbers of individuals with disabilities (IWD) in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) postsecondary education programs, and ultimately in the STEM workforce in Hawai‘i. Project was funded from October 1, 2009 for five years and continued with no-cost extension until September 30, 2017.

The project goals/objectives were as follows:

Goal/Objective 1: Increase the recruitment of IWD in high schools on Oahu who enroll in STEM degree programs at partnering 2 and 4 year IHE by 20% per year.

Goal/Objective 2: Increase the graduation rates (associate, baccalaureate, and graduate degrees) for STEM students with disabilities in Oahu based community colleges and university partner institutions by 10% per year.

Goal/Objective 3: Increase successful entry (employed) rates of Alliance graduates (high school, associate, baccalaureate, and graduate) into STEM employment by 5%.

Pacific Alliance was not able to meet all of its goals. For GOAL 1: the number of high school participants who graduated and entered college to major in STEM increased from 0 in Year 1, 7 in Year 2, 31 in Year 3, 43 in Year 4, and 36 in Year 5. Although the project did not meet the annual 20% increase goal in Year 5, it achieved the goal in Years 2, 3, and 4.

For GOAL 2: about AA/AS in STEM, the number of community college participants who graduated with STEM degrees or transferred to a 4-year university to study STEM increased from 0 in Year 1, 2 in Year 2, 5 in Year 3, 5 in Year 4, and 3 in Year 5. About BA/BS in STEM, the project had none in Years 1 and 2, 1 in Year 3, 3 in Year 4, and 1 in Year 5. About a graduate degree in STEM, the project had none in Year 1, 1 in Year 2, 0 in Years 3 and 4, and 1 in Year 5. The project did not make a consistent annual 10% increase in the postsecondary STEM degree attainment of participants.

For GOAL 3 outcome: the number of Pacific Alliance graduates who worked “full-time” in STEM was 0 in Year 1, 1 in Year 2, 1 in Year 3, 1 in Year 4, and 0 in Year 5. The project failed to make a consistent, annual 5% increase. 

Though the project did not meet the percent increase, the project met implementation goals. The project was able to reach its target population and provide them with a variety of evidence-based activities and financial support. Overall, approximately 400 IWD participated. Project activities included capacity building, recruitment into the project, provision of evidence practices (mentoring, academic, career-related), and financial support (stipends and paid internships). 136 high school student participants transitioned into post secondary education and 117 students transitioned into postsecondary STEM programs.

In general, the Pacific Alliance participants found the activities to be useful in providing skills that they felt they needed to succeed in school and STEM careers, and that activities organized and implemented by Pacific Alliance contributed to their interest, motivation, self-efficacy, and STEM-related metacognitive awareness. Over half (60%) of high school students reported that the project participation made a helpful contribution to them entering college. Approximately half (47%) of the students also indicated that the project contributed to improved grades.  63.1% of participants reported the increase of their interest in STEM. 57.5% of participants reported the increase of their academic aspiration in STEM. 61.64% of participants reported the increase of their career aspiration in STEM.  Of the Pacific Alliance high school participants that graduated and entered college, most all (70-100%) chose STEM majors. 

Through ongoing participation in the Pacific Alliance activiites, those participants who were active during the first two years of their postsecondary program accumulated more STEM and general credits, were more likely to have continuous enrollment across four semesters, and were more likely to be on track for graduating on time than the Pacific Alliance participants who were not active in their first two years. Approximately 62% of students active in the Pacific Alliance project in the first two years were on track to graduate on time, which far exceeded the on-time completion at University of Hawaii at Manoa (44%) and University of Hawaii Community Colleges (28%–39%). 

The Pacific Alliance project also addressed institutional capacity for serving these students through communities of practice (COP) and workshops for service providers. COP members perceived that the project activities had a positive impact on students’ access to STEM programs. More than half of the COP members responding (60%) agreed or strongly agreed that the COP contributed to a broadening of access to STEM programs for underrepresented students, and up to 40% agreed that it led to an increase in students participating in STEM programs and policy change at their institutions. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/07/2018
Modified by: Kiriko Takahashi
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The overarching goal of the Pacific Alliance project was to significantly increase the numbers of individuals with disabilities (IWD) in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) postsecondary education programs, and ultimately in the STEM workforce in Hawai?i. Project was funded from October 1, 2009 for five years and continued with no-cost extension until September 30, 2017. The project goals/objectives were as follows: Goal/Objective 1: Increase the recruitment of IWD in high schools on Oahu who enroll in STEM degree programs at partnering 2 and 4 year IHE by 20% per year. Goal/Objective 2: Increase the graduation rates (associate, baccalaureate, and graduate degrees) for STEM students with disabilities in Oahu based community colleges and university partner institutions by 10% per year. Goal/Objective 3: Increase successful entry (employed) rates of Alliance graduates (high school, associate, baccalaureate, and graduate) into STEM employment by 5%. Pacific Alliance was not able to meet all of its goals. For GOAL 1: the number of high school participants who graduated and entered college to major in STEM increased from 0 in Year 1, 7 in Year 2, 31 in Year 3, 43 in Year 4, and 36 in Year 5. Although the project did not meet the annual 20% increase goal in Year 5, it achieved the goal in Years 2, 3, and 4. For GOAL 2: about AA/AS in STEM, the number of community college participants who graduated with STEM degrees or transferred to a 4-year university to study STEM increased from 0 in Year 1, 2 in Year 2, 5 in Year 3, 5 in Year 4, and 3 in Year 5. About BA/BS in STEM, the project had none in Years 1 and 2, 1 in Year 3, 3 in Year 4, and 1 in Year 5. About a graduate degree in STEM, the project had none in Year 1, 1 in Year 2, 0 in Years 3 and 4, and 1 in Year 5. The project did not make a consistent annual 10% increase in the postsecondary STEM degree attainment of participants. For GOAL 3 outcome: the number of Pacific Alliance graduates who worked "full-time" in STEM was 0 in Year 1, 1 in Year 2, 1 in Year 3, 1 in Year 4, and 0 in Year 5. The project failed to make a consistent, annual 5% increase. Though the project did not meet the percent increase, the project met implementation goals. The project was able to reach its target population and provide them with a variety of evidence-based activities and financial support. Overall, approximately 400 IWD participated. Project activities included capacity building, recruitment into the project, provision of evidence practices (mentoring, academic, career-related), and financial support (stipends and paid internships). 136 high school student participants transitioned into post secondary education and 117 students transitioned into postsecondary STEM programs. In general, the Pacific Alliance participants found the activities to be useful in providing skills that they felt they needed to succeed in school and STEM careers, and that activities organized and implemented by Pacific Alliance contributed to their interest, motivation, self-efficacy, and STEM-related metacognitive awareness. Over half (60%) of high school students reported that the project participation made a helpful contribution to them entering college. Approximately half (47%) of the students also indicated that the project contributed to improved grades. 63.1% of participants reported the increase of their interest in STEM. 57.5% of participants reported the increase of their academic aspiration in STEM. 61.64% of participants reported the increase of their career aspiration in STEM. Of the Pacific Alliance high school participants that graduated and entered college, most all (70-100%) chose STEM majors. Through ongoing participation in the Pacific Alliance activiites, those participants who were active during the first two years of their postsecondary program accumulated more STEM and general credits, were more likely to have continuous enrollment across four semesters, and were more likely to be on track for graduating on time than the Pacific Alliance participants who were not active in their first two years. Approximately 62% of students active in the Pacific Alliance project in the first two years were on track to graduate on time, which far exceeded the on-time completion at University of Hawaii at Manoa (44%) and University of Hawaii Community Colleges (28%–39%). The Pacific Alliance project also addressed institutional capacity for serving these students through communities of practice (COP) and workshops for service providers. COP members perceived that the project activities had a positive impact on students? access to STEM programs. More than half of the COP members responding (60%) agreed or strongly agreed that the COP contributed to a broadening of access to STEM programs for underrepresented students, and up to 40% agreed that it led to an increase in students participating in STEM programs and policy change at their institutions.
